```{=html}
<script>
// Hide all descriptions on page load
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
  const descriptions = document.querySelectorAll('.plot-description');
  descriptions.forEach(desc => {
    desc.style.display = 'none';
    console.log('Hiding on load: ' + desc.id); // Debug log
  });
});

function showDescription(id) {
  console.log('Showing description: ' + id); // Debug log
  document.getElementById(id).style.display = 'flex';
}

function hideDescription(id) {
  console.log('Hiding description: ' + id); // Debug log
  document.getElementById(id).style.display = 'none';
}
</script>
```
```{=html}
<style>
.plot-container {

  display: inline-block;

  height: 100%; /* Cover full image height */
  z-index: 1000; /* Ensure description is above image */

}

.plot-container:hover .plot-description {
```

::: g-col-6
::: {.plot-container onmouseover="showDescription('Color-CodedClustersDendrogram-desc')" onmouseout="hideDescription('Color-Coded Clusters Dendrogram-desc')"}
![Color-Coded Clusters Dendrogram](ColorCoded_Clusters.png){fallback="https://via.placeholder.com/300x300?text=Color-Coded Clusters+Plot"}

::: {#Color-Coded Clusters Dendrogram-desc .plot-description}
A color-coded cluster dendrogram is an enhanced version of the basic dendrogram where branches or clusters are colored differently to clearly distinguish the groupings formed by hierarchical clustering. This makes interpreting the tree much easier, especially for large datasets or when clusters overlap visually.
:::
:::
:::


::: g-col-6
::: {.plot-container onmouseover="showDescription('VerticalDendrogram-desc')" onmouseout="hideDescription('violinplot-desc')"}
![Vertical Dendrogram](Vertical_Dendrogram.png){fallback="https://via.placeholder.com/300x300?text=Vertical+Plot"}

::: {#Vertical Dendrogram-desc .plot-description}
A vertical dendrogram is a classic, user-friendly way to display hierarchical clustering results with the data points along the bottom and cluster merges represented by upward vertical lines, enabling easy interpretation of cluster hierarchy and distances.
:::
:::

::: g-col-6
::: {.plot-container onmouseover="showDescription('Horizontal Dendrogram-desc')" onmouseout="hideDescription('HorizontalDendrogram-desc')"}
![Horizontal Dendrogram](Horizontal_Dendrogram.png){fallback="https://via.placeholder.com/300x300?text=Horizontal+Plot"}


::: {#Horizontal Dendrogram-desc .plot-description}
A horizontal dendrogram is a tree-like diagram used to visualize hierarchical clustering results where the structure extends horizontally rather than vertically. In this layout, the individual observations or samples appear along the vertical axis, and the branches stretch left to right, representing how clusters merge step-by-step based on dissimilarity or distance.
:::
:::

::: g-col-6
::: {.plot-container onmouseover="showDescription('Classical Dendrogram-desc')" onmouseout="hideDescription('Classical-desc')"}
![Classical Dendrogram](Classical_Dendrogram.png){fallback="https://via.placeholder.com/300x300?text=Classical+Plot"}

::: {#Classical Dendrogram-desc .plot-description}
A classical dendrogram is the traditional tree-like diagram used in hierarchical cluster analysis to represent the nested grouping of objects based on their similarity or distance. It is a fundamental visualization tool that shows how clusters are formed progressively, starting from each individual object and merging step by step into larger clusters until all objects are grouped into one.
:::
:::

::: g-col-6
::: {.plot-container onmouseover="showDescription('Ward'slinkage-desc')" onmouseout="hideDescription('Ward's linkage-desc')"}
![Ward's Linkage](Ward's_Linkage.png){fallback="https://via.placeholder.com/300x300?text=Ward's_Linkage+Plot"}


::: {#Ward's linkage-desc .plot-description}
Ward's linkage is a hierarchical clustering method focused on minimizing the increase in total within-cluster variance (or error sum of squares) when merging clusters. It is widely used because it tends to produce compact, spherical clusters, making it popular in many applications like biological data, market segmentation, and more.
:::
:::

::: g-col-6
::: {.plot-container onmouseover="showDescription('Ward'slinkage-desc')" onmouseout="hideDescription('Rectangular Clusters-desc')"}
![Rectangular Clusters](Rectangular_Clusters.png){fallback="https://via.placeholder.com/300x300?text=(Rectangular_Clusters+Plot"}


::: {#Rectangular Clusters-desc .plot-description}
Rectangular clusters are simply the visual aids drawn as boxes around groups of points identified as clusters on dendrograms or heat maps to facilitate clear, intuitive interpretation of cluster structure in hierarchical clustering outputs.
:::
:::

::: g-col-6
::: {.plot-container onmouseover="showDescription('Ward'slinkage-desc')" onmouseout="hideDescription('Circular Dendrogram-desc')"}
![Circular Dendrogram](Circular_Dendrogram.png){fallback="https://via.placeholder.com/300x300?text=(Circular_Dendrogram+Plot"}


::: {#Circular Dendrogram-desc .plot-description}
A Circular Dendrogram is a radial, space-efficient alternative to the classical dendrogram, arranging hierarchical cluster branches in concentric circles around a center. It enhances visual clarity for large or complex datasets by providing a 360-degree view of similarity and cluster structures, making it a valuable tool for hierarchical data visualization.
:::
:::

::: g-col-6
::: {.plot-container onmouseover="showDescription('Ward'slinkage-desc')" onmouseout="hideDescription('Circular Dendrogram-desc')"}
![Coloured Rectangular Dendrogram](Colored_Rectangular_Dendrogram.png){fallback="https://via.placeholder.com/300x300?text=(Circular_Dendrogram+Plot"}


::: {#Coloured Rectangular Dendrogram-desc .plot-description}
A coloured rectangular dendrogram is an enhanced dendrogram visualization where clusters are not only enclosed in rectangular boxes but these boxes and the associated branches are also color-coded to clearly distinguish different clusters. This combination improves interpretability and presentation of hierarchical clustering results.
:::
:::
:::
